Sometimes I wonder what would have happened if I'd fought against this change instead of embracing it. I might still be struggling to fill classes, watching overhead costs eat away at profits, limited by the number of people who could physically show up at specific times.

 

Instead, I'm part of a movement that's bringing Pilates to women who need it most—the busy, the overwhelmed, the ones who've been putting everyone else first for so long they forgot what it felt like to prioritize their own strength and well-being.

 

The studio closures happening across the country aren't a tragedy. They're a transformation. And for instructors willing to evolve with it, the opportunities are limitless.

 

To my fellow instructors watching their studios struggle: don't mourn the old model. Embrace the new one. Your expertise is more valuable than ever—it just looks different now.

 

And to the women who've discovered the joy of Pilates at home: you're not missing out on anything. You're leading the way.

settings.gg8OoyVThmo_text:
Today, six months after losing my studio, I'm teaching more women than I ever reached before, helping thousands get their stress free classes done right from the comfort of their own home. I offer live virtual classes every morning, personalized form check sessions, and even one-on-one coaching calls.

 

The most surprising part? I'm earning more than I ever did with the studio overhead, and I'm reaching women who never could have made it to my physical location—moms with newborns, women with disabilities, people in rural areas without access to quality Pilates instruction.

 

My students tell me they love having that connection and expertise while maintaining the convenience that changed their lives. They're getting results they never achieved with sporadic studio visits because they're practicing consistently, sometimes daily.

 

"I love doing this before work. It sets me up for a great day!"  - Jessica one of my regular virtual students told me.

Another shared: "This workout really helped me relax. My anxiety had been getting worse lately, and being active really helps me deal with tension and chronic stress." -Marley
settings.ggDCTNtp4Dy_text:
For months leading up to our closure, I kept hearing the same story from my regular clients. Women who had been coming to my classes for years suddenly canceling their memberships. When I'd run into them at the grocery store, they'd light up and say things like "Sarah! I'm still doing Pilates every day now—I'm obsessed!"

 

Wait, what?

 

They'd tell me about how they were finally consistent with their practice, how they felt stronger than ever, how their back pain was gone and they'd discovered this newfound flexibility. One mom, Jennifer, told me she was doing Pilates twice a day and seeing remarkable changes in her body.

 

I was confused and, honestly, a little hurt. If they were loving Pilates so much, why weren't they coming to my classes?

 

Then Jennifer mentioned something that stopped me in my tracks: "I got this reformer for my home, and it's completely changed my relationship with exercise. I actually look forward to my workouts now instead of trying to squeeze them in between carpool and meetings."

 

A home reformer? I'd seen the ads, sure, but I never took them seriously. How could a piece of equipment at home possibly replace the studio experience, the community, the hands-on instruction?
settings.ggH2Fg0tfL-_text:
What I initially saw as the death of my career was actually the birth of something much bigger. The at-home reformer movement isn't killing Pilates—it's revolutionizing it. It's making this incredible practice accessible to women who couldn't fit studio schedules into their lives, couldn't afford $65 classes three times a week, or simply felt intimidated by the studio environment.

 

The women in my virtual classes aren't missing out on the "real" Pilates experience. They're having their own authentic experience, one that fits their actual lives instead of the lives they wish they had.

 

I see 69-year-olds who thought they were too old, moms with multiple young children who couldn't find childcare, women with chronic pain who needed the gentle precision of reformer work but couldn't travel to studios regularly. I see busy working women who struggled to balance career demands with their wellness goals, finally finding a solution that worked with their packed schedules instead of against them.

 

They're all finding what my former studio clients found: consistency, strength, flexibility, and that incredible mind-body connection that makes Pilates so transformative.

settings.ggNuUbPUH4C_text:
I'll never forget unboxing the Elevé reformer in my living room. It was beautiful—not like the clunky equipment I was expecting, but something that actually looked elegant in my space. Still, I approached it with all the skepticism of someone whose livelihood had been built on the idea that "real" Pilates happened in studios.

 

My first session lasted twenty minutes. Best of all? Zero commute. Zero rushing between appointments. Just me, my living room, and twenty minutes of uninterrupted movement.

 

Then the unexpected happened. After only a week, I was completely hooked. No more stressing about whether enough people would show up to my classes. No more watching the clock during sessions, worried about the studio's declining membership. Even my roommate, who had never shown interest in exercise, started asking if she could join me. Pilates became our daily ritual, a quiet 20-minute sanctuary before the chaos of the day began.

 

The movement felt exactly like the studio classes I'd been teaching for years. The resistance was smooth and precise. The engagement through my core was immediate and intense. But something was different—something I hadn't experienced in years of teaching others.

 

I was completely present. There was no clock-watching, no mental list of errands running through my head, no guilt about the time away from other responsibilities. Just me, my breath, and the pure joy of movement.

 

For the first time in months, I understood why my clients had chosen this over coming to see me.
settings.ggQXaKrWLOg_text: Breaking: After 6 Years Teaching Pilates, I Was Fired as Studios Close Nationwide— Now I understand why
settings.ggT-zTB93Mi_text:
The morning my studio manager called me into her office, I knew something was wrong. The awkward small talk, the way she couldn't quite meet my eyes—I'd been teaching at Club Pilates for six years, and this wasn't our usual check-in.

 

"Sarah, I'm so sorry, but we're going to have to let you go. Your Wednesday and Friday classes just aren't filling up anymore, and we can't justify keeping the slots open."

 

I sat there stunned. My classes had been packed for years. I'd built relationships with these women, watched them grow stronger, helped them through injuries and life changes. Not because we weren't good instructors, not because our classes weren't transformative, but because our clients simply stopped showing up.

 

At first, I blamed everything. The economy, people's priorities shifting, even social media for making everyone think they could do Pilates from a YouTube video. I was angry, heartbroken, and honestly, terrified about what came next.

 

What I didn't realize was that I was witnessing the beginning of a revolution that would completely change how women experience Pilates—and ultimately give me a career more fulfilling than I ever imagined.

settings.ggjs2QHMhgb_text:
After weeks of wrestling with my skepticism—and my wounded pride—I decided to investigate. If my clients were choosing something over my carefully crafted classes, I needed to understand what that something was.

 

I spent hours researching, reading reviews from women who sounded exactly like my former clients. Busy moms talking about finally finding consistency. Women in their 40s and 50s saying they felt stronger than they had in years. Over and over, they kept mentioning this home reformer—The Elevé—and how it had completely transformed their relationship with exercise.

 

The reviews weren't from fitness fanatics or influencers. They were from real women—women who sounded exhausted, overwhelmed, and desperately searching for something that would fit into their chaotic lives.

 

"I finally finished the whole class in one go! I feel like a rockstar. I underestimated how hard this was going to be."

 

"I started when I was 68 after having continual back problems. 8 years later, I'm more flexible than I have been in all of my life."

 

"Pilates has helped my SI joint issues more than ANYTHING. I've tried chiropractor, meds, CT guided steroid injections. Pilates has helped the most."

 

These weren't marketing testimonials. These were real women finding real relief and joy in their bodies again.

As I fell into my own daily practice, something unexpected happened. I started sharing my experience online—not as marketing, but simply because I was genuinely excited about what I was discovering. The responses were overwhelming.

 

Women were reaching out constantly, asking questions, wanting guidance on form, seeking the instructor support they missed from studio classes. They were creating online communities, sharing their victories and struggles, supporting each other through the journey.
 

That's when I realized the opportunity wasn't gone—it had just transformed.

 

I started offering virtual classes to small groups of women who had reformers at home. What began as a few friends became a thriving online community. These weren't impersonal fitness videos—they were live, interactive sessions where I could still provide the hands-on guidance and personal attention my clients craved, just through a screen instead of across a studio floor.
